thread.title: Offensive line's growth a key to fast start for Gators
thread.title_full: Offensive line's growth a key to fast start for Gators

author: Graham Hack
title: Offensive line's growth a key to fast start for Gators
text:
Offensive line's growth a key to fast start for Gators 
By Graham Hack Tue, Oct 6, 2015 @ 10:19 pm | updated Tue, Oct 6, 2015 @ 10:38 pm Photos AP The quick development of Florida's offensive line has helped quarterback Will Grier (7) lead the team to a 5-0 start this season. 
GAINESVILLE | In the spring, Florida coach Jim McElwain had an offensive line that, as he described it, was in a “really dark” place. 
Four members of the 2014 unit left for the NFL Draft — all were selected — and projected starter Roderick Johnson just suffered a career-ending spinal injury. 
The team barely had enough healthy players to field a full line, much less a competitive one. 
There were freshmen coming into the program for the 2015 season, but freshmen offensive linemen and SEC defensive fronts don’t normally mesh well. 
But somehow, five games into the season, the Gators are getting the job done up front. 
“Obviously, the influx of the new guys has been fantastic,” McElwain said of the line. “The young guys have been doing a pretty darn good job in there. I would say the biggest thing I see there is they’re starting to understand the value of communication.” 
That communication was on display Saturday night as the Gators only allowed two sacks to an Ole Miss front seven that is considered one of the best in the country. 
For an offensive line that had 10 combined starts entering the season — third-fewest nationally — and has at times played three true freshmen at once, it’s a testament to how rapid the growth has been. 
“It’s really surprising to me,” transfer offensive lineman Mason Halter said about the youngsters’ play. “From high school to college, it was a big jump even for me, and I didn’t play my freshman year. I’m really impressed with these kids. ... They’re learning at an exponential rate, and their potential is great.” 
One in particular is five-star freshman offensive tackle Martez Ivey, who missed the first two games of the year with a knee injury but has made an immediate impact upon his return. Although he hasn’t started, he’s been in the regular rotation at tackle and even saw time at guard during the 38-10 win over the Rebels. 
“He’s responding like a veteran,” Halter said of Ivey. “He’s obviously very good at offensive line in general, and he can kick into guard like that. He’s just a physical body in there, and he dominates defenders.” 
Halter believes part of the growth collectively up front came from facing Florida’s own defensive line each day in practice. 
The Gators are tied for sixth in the nation with 18 sacks this season and are tied for third with 46 tackles for loss. Halter says those guys have helped prepare the offensive line for its opposition. 
“Ole Miss had a great defensive line, but our defensive line is just, in my eyes, so much better,” Halter said. “I mean, I get to work one-on-one with Jon Bullard every day. It’s helped me so much.” 
As Florida gets deeper into its SEC schedule, even more growth will be needed as the tests get tougher — like Missouri this week, a team that ranks second nationally with 48 tackles for loss.
